author: unklebape
body:
Not looked too much into AMD and XLNX but some generic questions/sanity check/back of envelope calculations as food for thought:

**Bottom-up:**

1. What if the synergy of 300M does not realise? How does that impact the enterprise value?
2. Are you using a discount rate for June 2023 valuation? i.e. Is this PV or FV?

**Top-down:**

1. Annualised growth of 23.96%. How does that compare to TAM? Looking at comps; are Intel/NVDA/etc projected to gain/lose this amount as well?

You're looking at a CAGR of 20%. Taking CAPM; beta at 2.28 (have not calculated, just took Yahoo Finance) and a risk-free at 1% (approx. 10-year) you should be looking at a market rate of return of approximately 8-9%.  

Does this make sense?

Last century or so equity is 10% so makes sense but looking at a 2-3 year timeline there's an element of volatility (especially when u look at trailing 12-month returns and bull cycles) where if going for further analysis; can maybe look at a theoretical single stock portfolio and calculate Sharpe Ratio. 

E&OE

author: mannyyyyyy
body:
I think you are confused between what the technology is (quite exciting), and what the valuation is through the merger (nothing exciting). If $ACEV trades near NAV, well, there is a reason: poor multiples.

I already replied to someone else on $ACEV yesterday, if you want to understand my point of view. On top of what I wrote, I would also add the fact that most of their topline is linked to a single client (Intel). This is clearly not good.

  
\*\*\*\*\*\* My previous comment \*\*\*\*\*\*  
Let me, however, point a few things about your rationale, especially on P/Es as this seems to be a central point in your DD.

P/E for semis do not mean much, as :

(i) you're talking about actual P/E. Nobody cares about actual P/E. What matters is forward P/E (you pay for what you will get, not for what you could have gotten). What's Achronix's forward P/E? Nobody really knows. You assumed CY21 P/E will be equal to CY20 ($37), but looking at the merger presentation, the company projects a net income of $50.3mn in 2021e and $58.6 (see page 40). We're rather talking about a company trading at 40x its Q4-Q8 projected earnings. That's in-line with Xilinx, the most comparable semi manufacturer.

(ii) P/E can be ultra cyclical. For example, we can see forward P/Es as low as 3-4x on NAND/RAM players such as Micron, SK Hynix etc (check their multiples in 2018 for example if you don't trust me). Even in a very oligoplistic market + highly fragmented client base such as NAND/RAM, the top players can't just fix their own prices. The end market is just too big and the semi too commoditized ; all you can do as a manufacturer is hope for demand to stay solid / stocks turnover to increase / stocks to decrease, and you need to compress your OPEX/CAPEX as much as you can in a downturn. This is not easy, and this is why the NAND/RAM market has this oligopolistic configuration (a lot of companies just died in previous downturns). I know it sounds counter intuitive, but a low P/E for semis is a sign of (a) extreme cyclicality and (b) poor outlook for demand, hence why the market prefers not to assign any premium to the stock. What matters is the sustainability of your gross margin down to the operating margin (e.g. how fast can you adjust your production? Can you shutdown some operations without suffering too much? what happens it you loose a big client and need to keep your factories open? ... this is where the problems usually arise). We don't really know about this for Achronix. I read from their merger presentation an EBIT margin ranging from 16% in 2018 to <0% in 2019, 35% in 2020, and 32%-33% estimated in 2021/22e (page 40). These variations make it difficult to assess the real, long-term EBIT margin.

(iIi) you can't compare P/Es among different types of semis. NAND, RAM, FPGAs, GPUs, etc. we're talking different levels of profitability, different cycles, different clients and end markets.

(iv) P/E for a given company/semi can vary dramatically. Forward P/E for Xilinx, one of the closest comparables for Achronix, has historically been between 15x to 25x, and is now north of 45x. So what it is the true P/E for a FPGA manufacturer ?

(vi) you can look at other metrics (page 38). Achronix is valued at 11.2x 2021e Revenue and 32.1x 2021e EBITDA. These multiples are absolutely in line with Xilinx's.

All that to say that if you base your decision on multiples... well, you end up with a valuation for Achronix that is quite comparable to a similar player such as Xilinx, which a has a longer track record, continued strength and several end markets... There doesn't seem to be anything exceptional for Achronix in terms of multiples. ACEV trades below 10.5, that probably tells you something.

That being said (and this is why I might buy some), the company does not seem to be overvalued, and given that it is operating in a very specific niche (FPGAs), which is already a hot topic and will remain a hot topic for the future, with few, remaining listed competitors, I think it's worth owning it.

Source: [https://www.achronix.com/sites/default/files/docs/Achronix\_Ace\_Merger\_Presentation\_VF.pdf](https://www.achronix.com/sites/default/files/docs/Achronix_Ace_Merger_Presentation_VF.pdf)

author: jmark1m
body: I'm an electrical engineer and was speaking to a manufacturer rep who started pitching me Achronix.  He claims the big advantage is definately the IP.  They are willing to license this IP to people so they can move their designs to ASICS and have the TSMC's of the world build them.  To my understanding Xilinx will not do this, they want you locked into their parts.  I wasn't really sold on Achronix, but I can see how this model could be attractive to a lot of companies after hearing this.  I bought a few shares.

author: GradExMachina
body:
>	Did you work on Rosetta 2? 

No.

>	What does Apple’s memory model have to do with this?

Everything.

>	Why does the fact their memory model is different than ARM have relevance? You’re lingering in generalities here.

Makes it easier to swap between x86 code and native. I will explain.

>	Apple’s memory model is far different than standard PC memory because they have unified memory across the SOC.

That’s not it what I referred to with “memory model”. What you are thinking of is unified memory architecture that is shared between cpu and accelerators (ML/Linear algebra, GPUs), as is done on consoles by AMD in collaboration with Sony and Microsoft. But in reality it’s not “far different”. That’s not what I was referring to.

>	This wouldn’t help them with x86 emulation IMO. It does generally help with good performance, but not for raw ARM CPU to x86 CPU instructions. If anything, the extra hardware necessary to ensure coherence would cost performance in this area.

Yes, what you were referring to doesn’t matter in this case, except for faster instruction fetch. Note apple silicon has larger instruction cache than AMD/Intel cpus but that’s not it, though it helps in a non trivial manner.

>	The fact they can offload to accelerators makes up for this, but again, this wouldn’t be the case for CPU-CPU instruction emulation.

Accelerators are irrelevant here, except perhaps if AMD pulls off an fpga x86->arm transpiler in an arm cpu, remember they filed relevant patent for fpga execution units embedded in a cpu, they own Xilinx now and dabbed in arm cpus some years ago and I am already salivating. 

Okay onto the main topic. Rosetta2 uses ahead of time compiler (transpiler) to go from x86 to arm, so it’s not an emulation layer like Microsoft did.

The second important trick is with respect to memory ordering, more specifically with how memory access instructions are ordered and how changes are visible to other processing units. Remember, modern cpus execute out of order and employ a vast array of tricks and intricacies to make everything work [1]. Apple implemented a memory model that is compatible with Intel. Actually they implemented 2 models the arm one and one for Intel. When executing x86 code, the cpu itself changes operating mode so it stops using Arm’s memory ordering and switches to Intel’s more strict model. 

It isn’t as fast or intricate as Intel’s, but they don’t need to because they are aiming to remove it (it meaning x86 code).

[1] there’s an absolutely brilliant conversion between Jim Keller and Lex Friedman on Lex Friedman’s podcast on what cpus do with out of order and speculative execution.

author: ec429_
body:
29, British, got about £65k to invest & a solid income (partly in XLNX RSUs so I can't give an exact value, but it looks like I'll be saving up another £30k/yr or so).  I'm bullish on Brexit / Global Britain, but utterly distrust govts to repay their debts without inflating them away so expect sovereign defaults & devaluations worldwide (though whether that's coming in 3 years or 33 I couldn't say) which obviously pushes me away from gilts & bonds.  Objectives: house in ~5 years (but don't mind waiting another 5 if stocks happen to be in the crapper), whatever's left towards early retirement fund (separately I also have a pension fund which is relatively conservatively invested and is about £50k right now).
Currently planning on roughly:

* 25% vaulted gold
* 35% FTSE All-Share
* 5% FTSE 250 (VMID)
* 15% FTSE Developed World ex UK
* 9% FTSE Developed Asia Pacific ex Japan (VAPX)
* 3% Global Small Cap
* 8% Global Corp Bond

(Gold is through BullionVault; the rest with Vanguard, and includes maxing out my ISA allowance.)

Does this seem sensible?  Am I massively overdoing the UK tilt?  Why doesn't Vanguard have a FTSE Small Cap fund?  And any other questions you think I should have asked but didn't...

author: Standard_Train_230
body:
From Ameritrade news, I'm buying OPK:

10 Short Squeeze Candidates Under $10

8:36 am ET January 30, 2021 (Benzinga) Print

The movement of retail traders against hedge funds has caused several stocks to spike. Many of the top movers have been stocks that have a high percentage of their floated shares short, causing what’s known as a short squeeze.

Among the other themes of the high-flying stocks is that many of them started trading under $10 before their run-ups. AMC Entertainment (NYSE: AMC), BlackBerry Ltd (NYSE: BB) and Express Inc (NYSE: EXPR) were all stocks that were under $10 and saw huge increases.

Related Link: AMC, National Beverage And 8 More Heavily-Shorted Stocks To Watch

Here are 10 stocks that trade under $10 with large short percentages that could be short squeeze candidates:

Clovis Oncology Inc (NASDAQ: CLVS) is a biotechnology company. Currently, 42% of the float is short.

Senseonics Holdings, Inc. (NYSE: SENS) is a medical technology company; 34% of its float is traded short.

VBI Vaccines Inc. (NASDAQ: VBIV) develops vaccines for adults, children and newborns; 20% percent of the float is short.

Naked Brand Group Ltd (NASDAQ: NAKD) sells intimate, swimwear and apparel, and 33% of its float is short.

Precigen Inc (NASDAQ: PGEN) is a biotechnology company; 35% of its float is short.

Opko Health, Inc. (NASDAQ: OPK) is a pharmaceutical and diagnostics company, with 26% of its float short.

Lannett Company, Inc. (NYSE: LCI) is a generics pharmaceutical company; 25% of its float is short.

Dyanvax Technologies Corporation (NASDAQ: DVAX) is a biotechnology company that is seeing 24% of its float traded short.

United Microelectronics Corp (NYSE: UMC) is a semiconductor company that makes products for companies like Advanced Micro Devices, Inc. (NASDAQ: AMD) and Xilinx Inc (NASDAQ: XLNX). The company is seeing 21% of its float traded short.

TherapeuticsMD Inc (NASDAQ: TXMD) is a pharmaceutical company targeting women, and 25% of its float is short.

author: posture_
body:
True - but consider point 2 above. I'm thinking of them more like a startup with proven tech. Can they pull of the pivot is the question here. They are known for having pulled off a few successful pivots in the past.

> Throughout their history, Achronix has perfected the pivot, executing a sequence of smart marketing moves in usually-successful attempts to outflank their much larger competitors. During the two decades Achronix has been around, numerous other programmable logic startups have failed, careening headlong into the wrath of the Xilinx-Altera/Intel duopolistic juggernaut. Achronix has consistently beaten those odds and survived and thrived with well-timed, unexpected pivots in their strategy.  

([https://www.eejournal.com/article/punching-above-their-weight-achronix-beats-the-odds/](https://www.eejournal.com/article/punching-above-their-weight-achronix-beats-the-odds/))

author: j455b
body: I think -6% as they announced XLNX buy. It sucked.

author: lookatmetype
body: Similar to the Altera acquisition, where the promise was that both Altera and Intel would leverage their existing infrastructures in a synergistic fashion to make some grand product from combining x86 + FPGA, and it didn't pan out for them, I see no indication that anything would happen differently with Xilinx + AMD. The problem is that the software toolchains required to compile FPGA designs are just so drastically different than the software required for processors, and given that AMD does not really have a good software story (similar to Intel), I don't see them solving this problem where Intel failed. My prediction is that Xilinx will continue to operate as a largely independent entity within AMD and their balance sheets are going to be pretty much independent. Xilinx will continue targeting the existing FPGA market, maybe a little bit of ML cloud market where they can, but generally you are not going to see some amazing FPGA based product with an AMD CPU in it that's going to the increase market share greatly (and thus the stock price).

The movement of retail traders against hedge funds has caused several stocks to spike. Many of the top movers have been stocks that have a high percentage of their floated shares short, causing what’s known as a short squeeze.

Among the other themes of the high-flying stocks is that many of them started trading under $10 before their run-ups. AMC Entertainment (NYSE: AMC), BlackBerry Ltd (NYSE: BB) and Express Inc (NYSE: EXPR) were all stocks that were under $10 and saw huge increases.

Related Link: AMC, National Beverage And 8 More Heavily-Shorted Stocks To Watch

Here are 10 stocks that trade under $10 with large short percentages that could be short squeeze candidates:

Clovis Oncology Inc (NASDAQ: CLVS) is a biotechnology company. Currently, 42% of the float is short.

Senseonics Holdings, Inc. (NYSE: SENS) is a medical technology company; 34% of its float is traded short.

VBI Vaccines Inc. (NASDAQ: VBIV) develops vaccines for adults, children and newborns; 20% percent of the float is short.

Naked Brand Group Ltd (NASDAQ: NAKD) sells intimate, swimwear and apparel, and 33% of its float is short.

Precigen Inc (NASDAQ: PGEN) is a biotechnology company; 35% of its float is short.

Opko Health, Inc. (NASDAQ: OPK) is a pharmaceutical and diagnostics company, with 26% of its float short.

Lannett Company, Inc. (NYSE: LCI) is a generics pharmaceutical company; 25% of its float is short.

Dyanvax Technologies Corporation (NASDAQ: DVAX) is a biotechnology company that is seeing 24% of its float traded short.

United Microelectronics Corp (NYSE: UMC) is a semiconductor company that makes products for companies like Advanced Micro Devices, Inc. (NASDAQ: AMD) and Xilinx Inc (NASDAQ: XLNX). The company is seeing 21% of its float traded short.

TherapeuticsMD Inc (NASDAQ: TXMD) is a pharmaceutical company targeting women, and 25% of its float is short.

author: Investinwaffl3s
body:

XLNX earnings after hours on Monday means it is going to either bleed back down to $90 or stay completely flat. And honestly there is a way higher chance that it sells off heavy as opposed to moons. If it was going to run into ER today was the day

author: blanketmess
body:
LSCC if you want a semi with almost no downside.

Big FPGA makers (Xilinx/AMD Altera/Intel) pursued high perf accelerator market and left low power all to Lattice---conveniently, right about the time the company shuffled its executive team. It's gains are AMD-esque, but largely ignored because no one knows what the fuck an FPGA is. They're programmable chips; flexible and high performance. The negative is that they're expensive, but that's changing and now FPGA adoption is skyrocketing. You can stick them in every single machine out there: Industrial automation, robotics, AI, security, datacenter, communications, automotive and even PC. Lattice expects growth in every single segment. Lattice's only downside was the loss of Huawei and even then they expect healthy growth. That's how nuts the demand is.

author: ec429_
body:
> generally you are not going to see some amazing FPGA based product with an AMD CPU in it

No argument from me on that score.  (Apart from anything else, CPUs on board FPGAs are likely to remain ARM-dominated.)

Where I think the advantages will come from is in having a porous boundary for ideas, know-how and talent to move around between the FPGA and x86 sides.  For example, one of the exciting possibilities I see for FPGAs in the near future is JITting eBPF* into hardware, and AMD's expertise with pipeline design, register renaming hardware, data hazard avoidance and all that jazz could really come in handy for a project like that.  (Of course I can't comment publicly on whether or not Xilinx _is_ working on such a project; I'm just giving my view as a private citizen that it's something it _should_ be working on.)

* eBPF is a super big deal, at least in the kernel / systems space.  The tussle you should be focussing on is not Intel vs AMD or even x86 vs ARM, but (x86 + ARM) vs eBPF.  Little snippets of concurrent code tied to events makes for the kind of embarrassingly parallel workload that makes hardware offload really tasty, and I think FPGAs are better placed than GPUs for the job.

Oh, and obviously by acquiring Xilinx, AMD will be getting me as an employee, which is an asset worth the purchase price all by itself /s

Thanks for that input about XLNX, I'll take a look. 

It's for the long haul, five years+. I have no interest in trading.

author: ec429_
body:
> they still have a lot of the best talent and best practices engineering wise

I dunno about that.  When the first batch of speculative execution vulns came out, my impression as an engineer was "Spectre is an embarrassing mistake but one anyone could have made just from not knowing that this was a channel that needed to be protected against.  But *Meltdown* is the kind of cockup that should never have happened, and wouldn't if the people involved cared about building things right."  I think Intel has the same problem as Boeing, that they've grown complacent and lazy and lost the culture of excellence that made them a leader in the first place.  (For those of you with longer memories, I'm given to understand that something similar happened to HP after they spun off Agilent.)

Disclosure: I work for XLNX and am paid partly in stock.  But I was already an AMD fanboi before they announced they were buying us.

author: shortymcsteve
body:
What are you buying, stock or options? And how long are you planning to hold?

I think earnings will be great, especially given the huge covid boost. But sometimes the market has a weird reaction to AMD earnings so it's honestly hard to say - Just look how irrational the stock is right now over the new Intel CEO. If you are holding for a few months I wouldn't sweat about it, and if you're planning to hold long term then it might be worth buying Xilinx stock instead (if you think the buy out will happen). You would get 1.7234x AMD shares in return if it happens. 
If you're yoloing options then I suggest getting more advice from r/amd_stock

author: bondn00bie

body:
This was a fantastic read and mirrors some of my own thoughts regarding the market. I found it interesting that they're also stating that we will have a *"likelihood of low policy rates for the rest of our lives".* Which is the same thing that many commentators on this sub-reddit have also been saying.

For fun, [here's the historical performance](https://www.portfoliovisualizer.com/backtest-portfolio?s=y&timePeriod=4&startYear=1985&firstMonth=1&endYear=2020&lastMonth=12&calendarAligned=true&includeYTD=false&initialAmount=10000&annualOperation=0&annualAdjustment=0&inflationAdjusted=true&annualPercentage=0.0&frequency=2&rebalanceType=1&absoluteDeviation=5.0&relativeDeviation=25.0&showYield=false&reinvestDividends=true&benchmark=VFINX&portfolioNames=false&portfolioName1=Portfolio+1&portfolioName2=Portfolio+2&portfolioName3=Portfolio+3&symbol1=TDG&allocation1_1=5&symbol2=ADBE&allocation2_1=5&symbol3=ADSK&allocation3_1=5&symbol4=ANSS&allocation4_1=5&symbol5=INTU&allocation5_1=5&symbol6=PAYC&allocation6_1=5&symbol7=VRTX&allocation7_1=5&symbol8=ANET&allocation8_1=5&symbol9=MA&allocation9_1=5&symbol10=PYPL&allocation10_1=5&symbol11=V&allocation11_1=5&symbol12=ABMD&allocation12_1=5&symbol13=ISRG&allocation13_1=5&symbol14=ALGN&allocation14_1=5&symbol15=TTWO&allocation15_1=5&symbol16=ETSY&allocation16_1=5&symbol17=XLNX&allocation17_1=5&symbol18=MNST&allocation18_1=5&symbol19=FTNT&allocation19_1=5&symbol20=NOW&allocation20_1=5) of the "high growth" picks that JPM outlines on page 9 (equally weighted, thereby not optimized towards any specific metric), so we can revisit this in 2022 and see how they did. As a data point, historically, it looks like the running CAGR of this blend is around 40.64%. If someone wants to buy this allocation, they can do so quite simply via fractional shares.

author: 3SensitiveQuestions
body:
And how do you calculate market cap? # of outstanding shares TIMES the current market price of one share. Stock price DOES impact valuation. 

Example:
Xilinx has 245M shares outstanding 

Stock price for Xilinx is $148

Market cap is 245,000,000 x 148 = 36.2b

As long as the outstanding shares don't change, and the price of the stock keeps climbing, the valuation becomes much larger.

Lattice's stock price went up 500% since 2019. Did the number of outstanding shares decrease? No. Probably not. In fact, prior to 2019 it is was a penny stock so dilution probably ocurred ("offerings"). Since then, the valuation just kept on increasing and increasing.

AMD deserved $100 at their last earnings. But they also chose to purchase Xilinx at *1/3 of their market cap* - and it went up to $90 from $85 post earnings.

Significant dilution is coming to AMD shareholders, arguably AMD should be at $60. Not to mention, AMD is seriously overvalued even considering them take over much of Intel market cap (which seems unlikely now)
